data.title: Generali says to keep investment decisions in BPCE deal, won't cut stake
data.description:
Key points:
  • Deal under scrutiny by Italy's government
  • Rome worried about decision-making power over investments
  • Asset management JV to be Europe's biggest by revenue

Generali will remain in charge of decisions over how to allocate its own clients' savings under the asset management deal with France's BPCE, the insurer said, addressing concerns raised by Italy's government and two leading investors.

In a bid to smooth the deal's approval process, Generali also reassured in a statement on Tuesday that it did not plan to reduce its stake in the venture it is finalising with BPCE.

Generali and BPCE last month struck a non-binding accord to create Europe's largest asset manager by revenue, by combining their Generali Investments Holding (GIH) and Natixis Investment Managers units in a joint venture of which the subsidiaries would each own 50%.

The deal faces regulatory hurdles, especially in Italy, where the government is keen for domestic savings to keep supporting the refinancing of its large public debt.

Sources told Reuters last week that Rome wanted further guarantees that Generali will remain in full control of allocating savings collected in the country.

"The creation of the partnership would have no impact on the continuity of savings management policies entrusted by Italian clients to the Generali group's companies, which remain the owners of the assets and decide on their allocation", it said.

Italy must clear the deal under "golden power" legislation that gives it clout over firms it deems as strategic.

"Generali and its board of directors – just as it is the case today – will continue to define the strategic investment guidelines and asset allocation for the entire group", Generali said.

GIH has Taiwanese insurance Cathay Life as a minority investor with 16.75%, meaning Generali itself will hold less than 50% of the JV it is forming through GIH.

The insurer said the accord envisaged mechanisms to allow and regulate any exit from the venture after a certain period of time.

"It is however not Generali's intention to – nor are there any contractual provisions that could compel it to – reduce its stake or governance rights," it said.

From a tax perspective the deal does not imply any transfer of value outside Italy, the insurer said, adding that "it is indeed plausible that the Italian tax burden would increase".

Two major Generali investors - Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone and Delfin, the holding company of late billionaire Leonardo Del Vecchio - have concerns about the influence the French side could exert in the partnership, sources have previously said.

Directors appointed by the two shareholders voted against the Natixis deal, which is expected to close in early 2026.

data.title: COMMENT-The dollar is Trump's Achilles heel
data.description:
The dollar is Donald Trump's Achilles heel as its strength, stemming from his plans to help the United States, could undo any good that results from the trade war he is fuelling.

The stronger the dollar becomes, the larger U.S. trade deficits may become, with monetary policy effectively tightening and strangling the economy.

The dollar is already having a huge impact. Its trade-weighted value has boomed almost 6% since September, reaching a near two-decade peak last month.

While tariff threats have forced Mexico and Canada to the negotiating table, China's been quick to fight back, and for currencies, delays which prolong uncertainty could be just as potent as the tariffs themselves.

For those trying to hedge the future direction of currencies it remains prudent to adopt a defensive position that will support assets deemed safer. The dollar is the most liquid and safest of all.

While some money may flow toward Japan's yen and Swiss franc, both are undermined by monetary policy, which in the U.S. - where the balance sheet has been reduced and interest rates are set to remain high - supports the greenback.

There is great potential for the dollar to rise further and should this sledgehammer approach to policy turn a spat into a war, the U.S. currency could rocket.

For more click on

data.title: Forterra Names New Chair Designate
data.description:
Forterra appointed Nigel Lingwood as its chair designate, effective April 1, according to a Tuesday filing.

Lingwood will succeed Justin Atkinson, who will step down and retire following the UK-based building materials company's annual general meeting on May 20.

data.title: Nivea Owner Beiersdorf's Sales Could Be Hurt by U.S. Tariffs — Market Talk
data.description: Beiersdorf's sales in the U.S. are expected to be hit by Trump's tariff proposals should they come into force, as about two-thirds of the sales in the country are sourced from or manufactured in other countries, a company spokesperson says. The owner of Nivea skincare products is monitoring the international backdrop as it plans potential measures to "adapt to new developments", the spokesperson adds, without disclosing further details. "The U.S. market remains a strategic growth market for Beiersdorf, which we intend to expand further in the coming years. We have already invested in the U.S. market in recent years and continue to build on this". Beiersdorf's sales in North America in 2023 represented nearly 13% of its total sales. Shares are down 1.2% and more than 10% over a 52-week period. (michael.susin@wsj.com)

data.title: Global Equities Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Equities. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires throughout the day.

0932 GMT - Beiersdorf's sales in the U.S. are expected to be hit by Trump's tariff proposals should they come into force, as about two-thirds of the sales in the country are sourced from or manufactured in other countries, a company spokesperson says. The owner of Nivea skincare products is monitoring the international backdrop as it plans potential measures to "adapt to new developments", the spokesperson adds, without disclosing further details. "The U.S. market remains a strategic growth market for Beiersdorf, which we intend to expand further in the coming years. We have already invested in the U.S. market in recent years and continue to build on this". Beiersdorf's sales in North America in 2023 represented nearly 13% of its total sales. Shares are down 1.2% and more than 10% over a 52-week period. (michael.susin@wsj.com)

0924 GMT - Malaysia's benchmark Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended 0.7% higher at 1564.56, mirroring gains in regional indexes, as markets reacted with tepid optimism. Trump's plan to talk with Beijing raised hopes for a U.S.-China tariff reprieve, FSMOne analyst Alwyn Chew Chuan Shyn says. For now, the market doesn't seem too concerned that China announced retaliatory tariffs on some U.S. goods, he adds. Still, Chew expects volatility in the local market to rise as investors closely monitor the U.S. and Malaysian earnings seasons and Trump's foreign policies. He sees support for the KLCI at 1535 and resistance at 1590. Among gainers, CIMB Group rose 2.4% and Sunway Bhd. climbed 2.3%. Meanwhile, Nestle (Malaysia) lost 1.8% and Petronas Chemicals was 1.4% lower. (yingxian.wong@wsj.com)

0916 GMT - Crest Nicholson's growth prospects will be limited despite management expecting sales rates to increase as it will be operating fewer outlets, Quilter Cheviot's Oli Creasey says in a note. The housebuilder has guided for volumes in 2025 to be similar to 2024 despite the forward order book being down 40% when compared to last year, with guidance overall cautious as most of the recovery is expected to come in 2H, Creasey says. Shares are down 0.5% at 174.20 pence, and are up 3.1% in the year-to-date. (anthony.orunagoriainoff@dowjones.com)

0914 GMT - BNP Paribas reported strong underlying trends for the fourth quarter and consensus expectations could rise, RBC Capital Markets analyst Anke Reingen says in a research note. The French bank's quarterly result as well as it CET1 ratio exceeded expectations, the analyst says. The bank's new 2024-2026 net income growth rate target suggests at least a 4% consensus upgrade, Reingen says. The slight fall in the bank's 2025 return on tangible equity to 11.5% from a range of 11.5% to 12% previously, given consensus expectations at 10.4%, should offer relief to investors fearing a steeper downgrade. BNP Paribas' targeted revenue growth of at least 5% per year for 2025-2026 is also higher than investors had expected. BNP shares trade 2.5% higher to 65.94 euros. (pierre.bertrand@wsj.com)

0910 GMT - BNP Paribas's fourth-quarter profit exceeded market views thanks in part to its corporate and institutional banking business, Barclays analyst Flora Bocahut says in a research note. The company's commercial, personal banking and services division also drove the 4% consensus beat, the analyst says. BNP Paribas's investment and protection services unit disappointed but the business should benefit later this year from external growth, the analyst says. Meanwhile, the bank's targets for 2026 are slightly ahead of consensus, the analyst says. BNP Paribas shares trade 2.7% higher at 66.09 euros. (pierre.bertrand@wsj.com)

0859 GMT - Dassault Systemes' new guidance for the current quarter and 2025 as a whole is slightly below market expectations, Bryan Garnier's Aurelien Deside writes in a note to investors. The French software maker is forecasting non-IFRS total revenue between nearly 1.54 billion euros and 1.60 billion euros for the first quarter and between 6.55 billion euros and 6.65 billion euros for the full year. Deside notes that projections for both periods are about 2% below consensus. Dassault Systemes shares trade 0.2% lower at 37.29 euros. (mauro.orru@wsj.com)

0853 GMT - Diageo's 1H performance was satisfactory and likely exceeded market expectations, with signs of stabilization as sales were up by 1% and profits down by 1%, Quilter Cheviot's Chris Beckett says. Diageo's decision to remove medium-term guidance of 5%-7% organic sales growth might upset some investors. However, this move is acceptable given that the target was laid during the pandemic--when demand for alcohol was exceptionally high--and unrealistic given the current environment, Beckett writes in a note. Additionally, the owner of Johnnie Walker, Guinness and Smirnoff seems to be effectively managing its significant debt, given that the dividend remained unchanged amid concerns of a potential cut, Beckett says. Diageo's 2H performance is likely to be similar if U.S. tariffs are not imposed, he adds. Shares are down 3.3% and nearly 20% over the last 52 weeks. (michael.susin@wsj.com)

0849 GMT - U.K. investors are on edge as trade jitters continue, Hargreaves Lansdown's Matt Britzman writes. Trade tensions are dictating the market mood, especially in Europe where U.S. President Trump keeps the continent guessing with lingering threats, the senior equity analyst writes. With volatility set to remain, there may be chances for investors to cash in on market overreactions, especially if Trump's tariff threats are a bluff, the analyst says. The U.K.'s FTSE 100 trades down 0.4%. (adam.whittaker@wsj.com)

0846 GMT - Diageo's withdrawal of its mid-term target is broadly positive given that it brings the company's aspirations to a more realistic level, RBC Capital Markets' James Edwardes Jones and Wassachon Udomsilpa say. The owner of Johnnie Walker, Guinness and Smirnoff reported a positive performance for the first half, ahead of market expectations. Meanwhile, full-year guidance reflects a sequential increase in organic sales growth and a slight decline in organic EBIT, the analysts write in a note. The guidance removal is welcome as it led to unrealistic investor expectations and sub-optimal management decisions designed to support an unfeasible growth aspiration. The target has been replaced by more comprehensive short-term guidance with the promise of improved productivity efforts and tighter capital discipline, they say. Shares are down 2.7% and nearly 20% over the 52-week period. (michael.susin@wsj.com)

0838 GMT - Staffline results buck the negative trend seen in the professional recruitment industry, Panmure Liberum analysts say in a research note. The London-listed recruitment-and-training group posted earnings before interest and taxes and net cash ahead of expectations, despite market concerns to the contrary, Panmure Liberum says. The company's U.K. recruitment business is gaining market share through deeper penetration of customers and new customers wins, the analysts say. Staffline's Ireland recruitment business is relatively stable, they add. Meanwhile, the PeoplePlus division has suffered delays but still benefits from a strong pipeline, the investment bank adds. Shares rise 27% to 23.90 pence.(maitane.sardon@wsj.com)

0829 GMT - Hong Kong shares ended higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 2.8% to 20789.96. The Hang Seng Tech Index added 5.1% to 4977.38. Investors were closely monitoring for the latest tariff-related developments from the U.S., Mexico, Canada and China. Trade tensions are likely to accelerate China's domestic economic reform, while major U.S.-China currency agreements are unlikely to take place, HSBC analysts write in a research note. Among major stocks, technology names led the gains, with Meituan rising 6.0% and Alibaba adding 4.0%. Lenovo was 6.9% higher. Decliners included Greentown China, which was 2.25% lower, and Shenzhen Pagoda Industrial, which dropped 4.9%. (tracy.qu@wsj.com)

0824 GMT - Singapore banks' 4Q 2024 earnings are likely to be resilient, says Yeap Jun Rong, IG's market strategist in a note. The bulk of the banks' earnings, which remain supported by net interest income, is expected to stay resilient amid the high-for-longer interest rate environment, he writes. The banks' 4Q loan momentum may also see some pick-up, with data suggesting that overall loans have risen in December from November, he says. Higher confidence around the economy with Singapore's low unemployment rate could have partly contributed to an improvement in lending conditions, Yeap adds. (amanda.lee@wsj.com)

data.title: DS Smith Delists from London Bourse after Takeover
data.description:
DS Smith (SMDS.L) shares were delisted and ceased trading on the London stock exchange on Tuesday following its acquisition by International Paper, according to a same-day filing.

The US-based company's takeover of the British packaging company became effective on Sunday.

data.title: Crest Nicholson's Fire Remediation Measures Are Reassuring — Market Talk
data.description: Crest Nicholson reiterating its fire safety remediation actions is reassuring, RBC Capital Markets analyst Anthony Codling says in a note. The year-end remediation charges stand at 249 million pounds, compared with January's guidance range of 245 million pounds to 255 million pounds, he says. The housebuilder's remediation program is expected to be completed during 2029, addressing any lingering concerns regarding its future legacy fire-related liabilities, and giving greater confidence in its valuation and business case, he says. "While the guidance midpoint is lower than consensus, we welcome the reiteration of fire safety remediation after an audited review, and the news of a strategy update in March," Codling says. Shares are down 0.5% at 174.20 pence.(anthony.orunagoriainoff@dowjones.com)

data.title: Investment Evolution Credit Names CEO Successor, Scraps Executive Chair Appointment
data.description:
Investment Evolution Credit (IEC.AQ) appointed Richard Leaver as its new chief executive officer, succeeding Marc Howells, who resigned to pursue other business interests.

Leaver's appointment as CEO took effect on Sunday, according to a Tuesday release.

Meanwhile, the British financial technology group will not move forward with appointing John Philip de Blocq van Kuffeler as executive chairman. His appointment was subject to standard regulatory approval.

data.title: Standard Chartered Appoints Maria Ramos as Chair
data.description:
By Cristina Gallardo

Standard Chartered said it appointed Maria Ramos as chair, succeeding Jose Vinals.

Ramos will take over following the company's annual general meeting on May 8, the bank said Tuesday. At that moment, Vinals will also retire from the board, it added.

Ramos, a former banker and chief executive of Absa Group Limited, has served as chair of the board risk committee and senior independent director at Standard Chartered.

She currently serves as a nonexecutive director on the board of Compagnie Financiere Richemont, from which she will step down after 13 years on March 31.

Write to Cristina Gallardo at cristina.gallardo@wsj.com

data.title: Kion Group: Efficiency Program to Save EUR 140M to 160M Per Year
Nokia Signs Multi-year Voice Core Expansion Deal with AT&T
data.description:
Telecoms equipment company Nokia received a multi-year expansion for its voice core deal with US telecom operator AT&T.

The expanded deal includes Nokia 5G IMS Voice Core and Nokia Digital Operations software, according to a Tuesday release.

data.title: Russian 10-Year Yield Rises to 3-Month High
data.description:
The yield on the Russian 10-year OFZ soared over 16.5% in February, the highest since reaching the post-Ukrainian invasion high of 17% in November of 2024 amid the ample supply of government bonds, lower demand for Russian assets from global markets, and lingering concerns of tighter monetary policy.

Surging inflation due to a plunging ruble, a labor-force crisis, and altered supply chains in response to sanctions drove the central bank to deliver 13.5 percentage points in rate hikes in the year.

Throughout policy statements, the central bank noted that expansionary fiscal policy and the large-scale military spending by the Kremlin contributed to inflation in Russia, financed in part through record levels of OFZ issuances through auctions.

In the meantime, the central bank faced political pressure to do refrain from raising rates, as dovish calls from President Putin and Russian business leaders drove the CBR to hold rates unchanged last meeting despite its signal of further hikes.

data.title: Kion Group: Cost Savings of Efficiency Program Effective 2026
Hong Kong's Q4 GDP Rises Amid Trade Tensions
data.description:
Hong Kong's gross domestic product or GDP grew in the fourth quarter of 2024 as the economy accelerated despite global trade risks.

GDP increased year on year by 2.4% during the quarter, compared to the 1.9% growth in the third quarter, Hong Kong's Census and Statistics Department said in its Monday release.

For the entire 2024, GDP rose by 2.5% in real terms over 2023, the C&SD said.

"Total exports of goods resumed growth amid improved external demand. Exports of services continued to increase, driven by further growth of visitor arrivals and improvement in other cross-border economic activities," a government spokesperson said in the C&SD statement.

Services exports jumped 5.6% during the fourth quarter, higher than the third quarter's 2.9% growth. Imports of services climbed 8.7%, albeit a slight increase from 8.9% a quarter ago.

The trading of goods eased on the other hand. Exports of goods increased by 1.2% from a year earlier, moderating from the third quarter's 4% rise. Goods imports slightly added 0.1%, lower than the 2.8% growth in the previous quarter.

The spokesperson said Hong Kong's economy is expected to grow further this year despite uncertainties, especially in the international markets. US President Donald Trump's trade tariffs may affect exports.

"They may also lead to a slower pace of interest rate cuts in the US and keep the Hong Kong dollar strong for longer," the spokesperson said.

data.description: Shell said on Tuesday it has restarted production at the Penguins field in the UK North Sea with a modern floating, production, storage and offloading (FPSO) facility.

data.title: Malaysian Shares Rebound on US Tariff Pause; Sunway REIT's Shares Rise Over 3%
data.description:
Malaysian stocks rebounded to end in the green zone on Tuesday on bargain hunting. The sentiment improved following the news of delayed import tariffs hike proposed by the US on Mexico and Canada on Monday.

The benchmark FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI, the main gauge of Malaysian stocks, gained 10.93 points to end 0.70% higher at 1,564.56. The day range was between 1,554.59 and 1,564.97.

In corporate news, shares of Sunway REIT gained over 3% on close after its distribution per unit or DPU jumped 14.1% year over year in the fourth quarter of 2024 to 5.34 ringgit from 4.68 ringgit a year earlier. Realized profit for the period attributable to unitholders soared 29.1% to 94.7 million ringgit from 73.4 million ringgit.

Shares of Ahmad Zaki Resources gained over 2% after it secured a deal worth 63.5 million ringgit from the Government of Malaysia for the construction and completion of the Bridge in Pahang, Malaysia.

Meanwhile, Malakoff agreed to sell 10 million shares, representing 100% equity interest in Malakoff Utilities for 65.5 million ringgit in cash. Its shares closed flat.

data.title: Kion Group Sees 2025 Cash Flow Below Market Expectations
FTSE Straits Times Index Closes 0.1% Lower at 3823.01
Dhanuka Agritech's Consolidated Net Profit Rises in Fiscal Q3
data.description:
Dhanuka Agritech said its consolidated net profit rose to 550.4 million Indian rupees in the fiscal third quarter from 453.7 million rupees a year ago, according to a Monday filing with the Indian exchanges by the insecticides company.

Earnings per share during the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2024, climbed to 12.25 rupees from 9.95 rupees a year earlier.

Revenue from operations increased year on year to 4.45 billion rupees from 4.03 billion rupees, according to the filing.

data.title: Qatar Non-Oil Private Sector Growth Moderates at Start of 2025
data.description:
Qatar's S&P Global PMI fell to 50.2 in January 2025 from 52.9 in December, indicating a slowdown in non-energy private sector growth.

While business conditions remained in expansion territory, the pace of improvement eased due to weaker construction demand.

Meanwhile, the labor market remained strong, with job creation at historic levels, though employment growth softened slightly.

Wage inflation also reached a new peak amid strong demand for skilled labor.

However, new business dropped for the first time in over a year, mainly due to lower construction demand, though manufacturing and wholesale sectors saw strong orders.

Regarding prices, firms managed costs well, with selling prices falling for the sixth month and supply chain conditions improving with faster delivery times.

Looking ahead, sentiment remained positive, driven by expectations of strong demand in tourism, industrial development, and real estate.

data.title: Kion Group 2024 Sales EUR11.50B
Reinsurer Scor rises on January renewals growth
data.description:
** Shares in Scor rise 3.7%, among top performers on Europe's STOXX 600 index , after the French reinsurer published positive renewals result for January 2025

** Its estimated gross premium income (EGPI) grew 9.6% on January's P&C renewals

** J.P.Morgan notes continued growth in 2025, sees the renewals "as being mildly supportive" for Scor

** Profit delivery rather than top-line growth remains the "key sticking point" for the market, JPM adds

** Scor says the expected net technical profitability remains unchanged for the renewed portfolio

** The shares are on track for their best day in two months if the gains hold

($1 = 0.9675 euros)
